questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case? ( NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

questions.text: A patient presented with follicular hyperkeratosis on the extensor aspect of the forearm. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phrynoderma is linked to vitamin A deficiency and presents as follicular hyperkeratosis, particularly on extensor surfaces like the forearm.

questions.text: What is the dye and filter used as seen in the image? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

options.label: D
options.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under green filter

questions.correct_answer: A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In ophthalmology, different dyes and filters are used to aid in the diagnosis of various conditions. Fluorescein dye is visualized using a cobalt blue filter, which causes it to fluoresce and highlights areas of corneal compromise. It is crucial to use the appropriate filter for each dye to accurately diagnose and assess ocular surface disorders.

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: C. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury after thyroidectomy is a serious complication that can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. Immediate recognition and management are crucial to ensure the safety and recovery of the patient.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 339
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 339

questions.text: Which vaccine is not safe in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Varicella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ All live vaccines except yellow fever are contra-indicated due to the theoretical risk of fetal infection and teratogenicity
  • ➤ except yellow fever

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with severe abdominal distension, pain, and absolute constipation for the past two days. Physical examination reveals a distended, tympanic abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sigmoid volvulus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The case presents classical features of sigmoid volvulus, which is confirmed by the radiological findings showing:
  • • Classic "coffee bean" sign - two dilated bowel loops without haustra Common in elderly patients Presents with severe abdominal distension and constipation The diagnosis is supported by typical patient demographics (elderly) and clinical presentation (constipation, distension). Sigmoid volvulus is the most common type of colonic volvulus, particularly in older patients with chronic constipation.
  • • Classic "coffee bean" sign - two dilated bowel loops without haustra
  • • Common in elderly patients
  • • Presents with severe abdominal distension and constipation The diagnosis is supported by typical patient demographics (elderly) and clinical presentation (constipation, distension). Sigmoid volvulus is the most common type of colonic volvulus, particularly in older patients with chronic constipation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Small bowel volvulus : Shows different radiological pattern with "step ladder" appearance of dilated small bowel loops. Small bowel shows complete mucosal folds (valvulae connivence’s), unlike the pattern seen here.
  • • Option A. Small bowel volvulus
  • • Option B. Intestinal obstruction : While present here, this is a general term. The specific type (sigmoid volvulus) can be identified by the characteristic radiological appearance. Small bowel obstruction shows complete mucosal folds, while large bowel obstruction shows haustra.
  • • Option B. Intestinal obstruction
  • • Option D. Caecal volvulus : Shows a single dilated loop with haustral pattern forming a "C" sign, unlike the double-loop "coffee bean" appearance seen in sigmoid volvulus. Cecal volvulus is less common than sigmoid volvulus.
  • • Option D. Caecal volvulus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sigmoid volvulus presents with the characteristic "coffee bean" sign on X-ray (two dilated loops without haustra) and typically occurs in elderly patients with chronic constipation.
  • ➤ Sigmoid Volvulus vs Cecal Volvulus

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with a history of pathological fracture of the neck of femur. On lab investigations, ALP and N-telopeptide levels were raised. The DEXA scan confirmed the diagnosis as osteoporosis. Based on the lab values of osteoporosis, which other values will be raised in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tartrate Resistant Acid Phosphatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption, making it a key marker for this condition.
  • ➤ Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP)

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.

questions.text: Identify the instrument: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal airway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nasopharyngeal airway (NPA) is a flexible tube used to secure an airway via the nasal passage, especially in patients who are semi-conscious and have an intact gag reflex.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient, on treatment for infertility, came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Single dose methotrexate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy, beta hCG levels < 5000 IU/L, gestational sac size < 3.5 cm, and no fetal cardiac activity, single-dose methotrexate is the most appropriate management option.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25 th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25 th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months. What is the next best investigation to do? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) UPT

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a 28-year-old woman with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months, the first step is to rule out pregnancy. The initial investigation in this scenario should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT). This is crucial because pregnancy-related complications such as threatened abortion, incomplete abortion, or ectopic pregnancy can present with irregular bleeding. Identifying or excluding pregnancy is the most immediate concern and guides subsequent management.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. TVS (Transvaginal Ultrasound): This is a valuable tool for assessing pelvic pathology and uterine abnormalities, but it is typically done after confirming the UPT results.
  • • Option B. TVS (Transvaginal Ultrasound):
  • • Option C. Pap smear: This test is used for cervical cancer screening and is not the immediate next step in evaluating irregular bleeding when pregnancy needs to be ruled out first.
  • • Option C. Pap smear:
  • • Option D. USG abdomen: While an abdominal ultrasound can provide useful information, it is less sensitive than a transvaginal ultrasound for early pregnancy detection and pelvic pathology assessment.
  • • Option D. USG abdomen:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a reproductive-age woman with irregular bleeding, the first investigation should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT) to rule out pregnancy-related causes.

questions.text: A patient presented with features as given in the image below.What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  Arsenic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mees' lines and raindrop pigmentation of the skin are classic signs of arsenic poisoning. In the absence of alopecia, arsenic is the preferred diagnosis over thallium.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) presents to the OPD with seizures, headache, vomiting, and photophobia. On further evaluation, homonymous hemianopia and episodes of epilepsy were observed. A CT scan of the brain was performed What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Temporal abscess

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presentation indicates temporal lobe abscess because:
  • • Clear space-occupying lesion in temporal lobe visible on CT Classic symptoms of temporal lobe involvement: Seizures indicating brain parenchymal involvement Homonymous hemianopia due to temporal lobe compression Increased intracranial pressure symptoms (headache, vomiting, photophobia) Common complication of CSOM due to: Direct extension through tegmen tympani Temporal lobe is most common site for brain abscess in CSOM
  • • Clear space-occupying lesion in temporal lobe visible on CT
  • • Classic symptoms of temporal lobe involvement: Seizures indicating brain parenchymal involvement Homonymous hemianopia due to temporal lobe compression Increased intracranial pressure symptoms (headache, vomiting, photophobia)
  • • Seizures indicating brain parenchymal involvement Homonymous hemianopia due to temporal lobe compression Increased intracranial pressure symptoms (headache, vomiting, photophobia)
  • • Seizures indicating brain parenchymal involvement
  • • Homonymous hemianopia due to temporal lobe compression
  • • Increased intracranial pressure symptoms (headache, vomiting, photophobia)
  • • Common complication of CSOM due to: Direct extension through tegmen tympani Temporal lobe is most common site for brain abscess in CSOM
  • • Direct extension through tegmen tympani Temporal lobe is most common site for brain abscess in CSOM
  • • Direct extension through tegmen tympani
  • • Temporal lobe is most common site for brain abscess in CSOM
  • • Temporal lobe is most common site for brain abscess in CSOM
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Meningitis
  • • Option B. Meningitis
  • • Most common intracranial complication of CSOM No discrete abscess formation on imaging Shows meningeal enhancement Different clinical features (neck rigidity, Kernig's sign)
  • • Most common intracranial complication of CSOM
  • • No discrete abscess formation on imaging
  • • Shows meningeal enhancement
  • • Different clinical features (neck rigidity, Kernig's sign)
  • • Option C. Subdural abscess
  • • Option C. Subdural abscess
  • • Collection between dura and arachnoid Different imaging appearance No discrete parenchymal involvement Different clinical presentation
  • • Collection between dura and arachnoid
  • • Different imaging appearance
  • • No discrete parenchymal involvement
  • • Different clinical presentation
  • • Option D. Extradural abscess
  • • Option D. Extradural abscess
  • • Collection outside dura but intracranial Different imaging appearance Less severe neurological symptoms No parenchymal involvement
  • • Collection outside dura but intracranial
  • • Different imaging appearance
  • • Less severe neurological symptoms
  • • No parenchymal involvement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of CSOM, presenting with seizures and characteristic CT findings of a space-occupying lesion in the temporal lobe.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Homogentisate oxidase

questions.text: In a 30-year-old female from a tribal area who presents with fever for the last 3 days, which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her illness based on the diagnosis of malaria made through examination of the peripheral smear? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) P. falciparum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identification of P. falciparum through the presence of distinctive ring forms in red blood cells on a peripheral smear is crucial for rapid initiation of appropriate antimalarial therapy, particularly in endemic regions. Early treatment is vital to prevent severe complications and reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: The given instrument is used for: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D) Low air velocity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Kata thermometer is primarily used today to assess low air velocity.

questions.text: Female on maize as a staple diet. History of diarrhea and lesion in the neck region. It is due to deficiency of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Causes of pellagra
  • ➤ Causes of pellagra
  • ➤ Maize and Jowar in Diet: The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Jowar has high content of leucine which inhibits tryptophan to Niacin conversion. Carcinoid syndrome: In this, Trp is mainly used for serotonin formation causes deficiency of trp for Niacin synthesis. Malabsorption Drugs like Isoniazid as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.
  • ➤ Maize and Jowar in Diet: The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Jowar has high content of leucine which inhibits tryptophan to Niacin conversion.
  • ➤ Maize and Jowar in Diet:
  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome: In this, Trp is mainly used for serotonin formation causes deficiency of trp for Niacin synthesis.
  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome:
  • ➤ Malabsorption
  • ➤ Malabsorption
  • ➤ Drugs like Isoniazid as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.
  • ➤ Drugs like Isoniazid

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

questions.text: Tracheal innermost layer has which epithelial lining? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified columnar epithelium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The innermost layer of the trachea is lined with pseudostratified columnar epithelium, which appears layered due to the positioning of cell nuclei but is actually a single layer of cells designed to protect the respiratory tract and facilitate mucus movement.

questions.text: Accidental death occurred in a man 3 days after the accident. During the postmortem examination, bleeding was observed in the head that was not washed away by water. This can be due to: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subarachnoid bleeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is identified by the persistence of bleeding in the head that is not washed away by water during an autopsy, due to its protection by the arachnoid mater

questions.text: Rice water diarrhoea, intoxication is due to which ganglioside?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GM-1 ganglioside receptor.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Rice water diarrhea is a characteristic symptom of cholera, which is caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae is the cholera toxin.
  • • The cholera toxin binds to the GM-1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. This binding leads to the activation of adenylate cyclase, increased levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP), and subsequent secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in the characteristic rice water diarrhea.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. GM-2 ganglioside receptor: GM-2 ganglioside is not related to cholera toxin binding. Instead, it is involved in diseases like Tay-Sachs and Sandhoff disease, where there is a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase, leading to the accumulation of GM-2 ganglioside.
  • • Option B. GM-2 ganglioside receptor:
  • • Option C. GM-3 ganglioside receptor: GM-3 ganglioside is not involved in the mechanism of cholera toxin. It is a simpler ganglioside involved in different cellular processes but not specifically in the pathology of cholera.
  • • Option C. GM-3 ganglioside receptor:
  • • Option D. GD-1a ganglioside receptor: GD-1a ganglioside is not associated with the cholera toxin. It has roles in neural cell function and development but does not play a part in the mechanism of action of cholera toxin.
  • • Option
  • • D. GD-1a ganglioside receptor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin binds to the GM-1 ganglioside receptor on intestinal epithelial cells, causing the characteristic rice water diarrhea by increasing cyclic AMP levels and promoting water and electrolyte secretion into the intestinal lumen.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 202

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented with hearing loss. On PTA, the amount of hearing loss was 56dB: (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis often presents as progressive conductive hearing loss with an intact tympanic membrane, and the hearing loss can worsen during pregnancy. The classic finding is ossicular fixation, particularly of the stapes bone.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows widened mediastinum. BP is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute aortic dissection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classic presentation of acute aortic dissection includes sudden severe chest pain radiating to the neck and back, a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray. Immediate imaging with a CT thoracic angiogram and lowering blood pressure are crucial steps in management.
  • ➤ The classic presentation of acute aortic dissection includes sudden severe chest pain radiating to the neck and back, a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.
  • ➤ Immediate imaging with a CT thoracic angiogram and lowering blood pressure are crucial steps in management.

questions.text: A patient with dyspnea, respiratory distress due to pan-acinar emphysema, and liver dysfunction is due to a likely defect in which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency is associated with pan-acinar emphysema and liver dysfunction due to a deficiency of the protective alpha 1 anti-trypsin protein.

questions.text: In a case of RTA (Road Traffic Accident), a person has died. Who can order an autopsy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Police Officer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Police Officer, specifically the Investigating Officer, has the authority to order an autopsy in cases of unexplained or suspicious deaths, such as those resulting from a road traffic accident.

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee and a high fever. X-ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Aspirate from the joint will most likely show: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Salmonella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.
  • ➤ Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Carcinoma Esophagus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical history of an elderly female presenting with symptoms such as progressive dysphagia, loss of appetite and weight loss along with the given barium study which shows irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins . These findings are suggestive of Carcinoma Esophagus.
  • • barium study which shows irregular narrowing,
  • • mucosal destruction and shouldered margins
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Diffuse esophageal spasm: Is a motility disorder of esophagus and appears as a corkscrew esophagus .
  • • Option A.
  • • Diffuse esophageal spasm:
  • • motility disorder of esophagus
  • • corkscrew esophagus
  • • Option B. Esophageal leiomyoma: Is a benign neoplasm of the esophagus and on barium swallow it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass well outlined by barium.
  • • Option B. Esophageal leiomyoma:
  • • benign neoplasm of the esophagus
  • • discrete ovoid mass
  • • Option D. Esophageal webs: Refers to an esophageal constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen .
  • • Option D. Esophageal webs:
  • • esophageal constriction
  • • thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an elderly patient presenting with progressive dysphagia for solids and significant weight loss, the presence of irregular narrowing and shouldered margins on a barium swallow is highly suggestive of esophageal carcinoma. Diagnostic confirmation typically requires upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) and biopsy. For tumor staging, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is used for T and N staging, while PET-CT is utilized for M staging.

questions.text: A firefighter with a history of smoke inhalation presents with fever, cough, and signs of lung consolidation. Sputum culture reveals colonies with a green pigment and fluorescence under UV light. Which organism is most likely? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa's characteristic laboratory features: green pigment (pyocyanin) production and fluorescence under UV light, particularly in the context of respiratory infections following airway damage.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever for 5 days and you are suspecting enteric fever. What is the best way to diagnose? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blood Cultures

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Enteric fever, commonly known as typhoid fever, is typically caused by the bacteria Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi. The best diagnostic method depends on the stage of the disease.
  • • For a patient presenting with fever for 5 days (in the first week of illness), blood cultures are the most reliable diagnostic method. During the first week, the bacteria are most likely to be present in the bloodstream, making blood cultures highly effective for identifying the pathogen.
  • • blood cultures
  • • Key points:
  • • Key points:
  • • Blood cultures: The best diagnostic method for enteric fever during the first week of illness, as the bacteria are present in the blood. Bone marrow cultures: While they have the highest sensitivity at any stage of the disease, they are more invasive and less commonly performed compared to blood cultures.
  • • Blood cultures: The best diagnostic method for enteric fever during the first week of illness, as the bacteria are present in the blood.
  • • Blood cultures:
  • • Bone marrow cultures: While they have the highest sensitivity at any stage of the disease, they are more invasive and less commonly performed compared to blood cultures.
  • • Bone marrow cultures:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Urine cultures: These are not typically useful in the early stages of enteric fever and are more relevant in the later stages of the disease.
  • • Option B. Urine cultures:
  • • Option C. Widal test: This serological test detects antibodies against Salmonella antigens, but it is less specific and sensitive, especially in the early stages. It also has a higher rate of false positives and is not recommended as the primary diagnostic tool in the first week.
  • • Option C. Widal test:
  • • Option D. Stool cultures: These can be useful later in the disease when the bacteria are shed in the stool, but they are not the best diagnostic method during the first week.
  • • Option D. Stool cultures:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For diagnosing enteric fever in the first week of illness, blood cultures are the most effective and reliable method.

questions.text: A football player had a twisting injury of the knee with no clinical bony injury. Which test is being performed here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lachman’s test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lachman’s test is the most reliable physical exam maneuver for diagnosing ACL tears, performed with the knee in 20-30 degrees of flexion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sertoli cell only syndrome : The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility. Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Sertoli cell only syndrome : The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility. Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Sertoli cell only syndrome
  • • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility. Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility.
  • • Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy.
  • • The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Testicular atrophy : Testicular atrophy may present with decreased testicular volume and could be due to various causes like mumps orchitis, trauma, or varicocele. The histopathological findings would not specifically show the absence of germ cells with the presence of only Sertoli cells.
  • • Option B. Testicular atrophy
  • • Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm : Benign testicular neoplasms would present with a mass in the testis and would show specific neoplastic cells on histopathology rather than the absence of germ cells.
  • • Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm
  • • Option D. Orchitis : Orchitis typically presents with inflammation, pain, and swelling of the testes, and the biopsy would show inflammatory infiltrates rather than the absence of germ cells.
  • • Option D. Orchitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by primary infertility and azoospermia, with testicular biopsy showing seminiferous tubules populated only by Sertoli cells and absence of germ cells.

questions.text: In a case of tinea capitis, white powdery colonies were isolated from the hair specimen. The hair perforation test was positive on the isolate. Which of the following is the likely etiology? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trichophyton mentagrophytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of tinea capitis, a positive hair perforation test indicative of surface erosion and wedge-shaped appearance of the hair shaft confirms the presence of Trichophyton mentagrophytes. This test is crucial for distinguishing it from other dermatophytes, specifically Trichophyton rubrum.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best antibiotic choice for a patient with otitis media who is allergic to penicillins? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For patients with penicillin allergy, azithromycin is the best choice because:
  • • For patients with penicillin allergy, azithromycin is the best choice because:
  • • It doesn't belong to β-lactam family, so no cross-allergenicity Can be administered orally unlike amikacin which needs injection Effective against gram-positive bacteria which commonly cause otitis media
  • • It doesn't belong to β-lactam family, so no cross-allergenicity
  • • Can be administered orally unlike amikacin which needs injection
  • • Effective against gram-positive bacteria which commonly cause otitis media
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ceftriaxone: Incorrect
  • • Option B. Ceftriaxone: Incorrect
  • • It's a cephalosporin which belongs to β-lactam family Contraindicated in patients with penicillin allergy due to cross-allergenicity
  • • It's a cephalosporin which belongs to β-lactam family
  • • Contraindicated in patients with penicillin allergy due to cross-allergenicity
  • • Option C. Amikacin: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Amikacin: Incorrect
  • • Although amikacin is safe in penicillin-allergic patients, it is primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria, while otitis media is commonly caused by gram-positive organisms.
  • • Although amikacin is safe in penicillin-allergic patients, it is primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria, while otitis media is commonly caused by gram-positive organisms.
  • • Option D. Meropenem: Incorrect
  • • Option D. Meropenem: Incorrect
  • • It's a carbapenem which belongs to β-lactam family Contraindicated in penicillin allergy due to cross-allergenicity
  • • It's a carbapenem which belongs to β-lactam family
  • • Contraindicated in penicillin allergy due to cross-allergenicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In penicillin-allergic patients, β-lactam antibiotics (penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems) are contraindicated due to cross-allergenicity. Azithromycin is a safe and effective alternative.

questions.text: Which tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus on inversion of the foot? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Posterior tibialis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot and inserts on the navicular bone.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents due to bowing of the legs. On examination, the child has widening of the wrists and frontal bossing. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rickets should be suspected in children with bowing of the legs, delayed fontanelle closure, and widened wrists. It is caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to defective bone mineralization.

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive investigations provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dobutamine stress echocardiography is the most accurate non-invasive investigation for predicting perioperative cardiac complications due to its ability to simulate exercise and identify areas of the heart with reduced blood flow.
  • ➤ Dobutamine stress echocardiography is the most accurate non-invasive investigation for predicting perioperative cardiac complications due to its ability to simulate exercise and identify areas of the heart with reduced blood flow.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 935
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg
  • ➤ 935

questions.text: A child is presenting with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Henoch-Schonlein purpura

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Henoch-Schonlein purpura is characterized by the presence of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis, and renal involvement, typically manifesting as hematuria and proteinuria. It is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly affecting children and is distinguished by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in affected tissues.

questions.text: A tumor marker analysis shows elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in a patient. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with increased AFP? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common malignancy associated with significantly elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels, making AFP an important diagnostic and monitoring marker for this cancer.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate behaviors such as self-induced vomiting (purging) or hypergymnasia to prevent weight gain. It is usually associated with fear of gaining weight. Purging can lead to dental caries, knuckle callouses, parotitis, hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis and rarely gastric or esophageal tear. Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.
  • ➤ episodes of binge eating
  • ➤ inappropriate behaviors
  • ➤ Weight is usually normal,

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 469

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image below.(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders. They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.
  • ➤ Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders.
  • ➤ They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury and his serum K+ level was found to be 5.5 mEq/L. What change will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient? ( NEET PG 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Becomes more positive

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In the given clinical scenario, the patient has hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can cause a shift in the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value, increased cell excitability, and impairments in membrane potential changes.
  • • Hyperkalemia can affect the resting membrane potential of cells, including neurons and muscle cells, in the following ways:
  • • Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value. Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli. Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials. Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.
  • • Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value.
  • • Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli.
  • • Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials.
  • • Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. No change: Incorrect. Changes in extracellular potassium concentrations directly impact the resting membrane potential.
  • • Option A. No change:
  • • Option B. Becomes more negative: Incorrect. An increase in extracellular potassium concentration results in depolarization (more positive resting membrane potential), not hyperpolarization.
  • • Option B. Becomes more negative:
  • • Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative: Incorrect. While complex fluctuations can occur under dynamic conditions, primarily, hyperkalemia causes a persistent depolarization (more positive shift) without an initial opposite change.
  • • Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hyperkalemia, as seen in patients with severe muscle injury, the resting membrane potential becomes more positive due to decreased potassium efflux, leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells. This can affect the normal function of these cells, potentially leading to complications such as muscle weakness or cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A cohort study was carried out involving individuals who consumed green tea and those who did not, aiming to examine its impact on diabetes mellitus. The calculated risk ratio stood at 0.84. Which of the subsequent statements is accurate? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Green tea increases the risk of diabetes

options.label: B
options.text: Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

options.label: C
options.text: Data insufficient to establish causal association

options.label: D
options.text: The value (0.84) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect

questions.correct_answer: B. Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed
  • ➤ Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed
  • ➤ Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)
  • ➤ Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with persistent symptoms of abdominal pain and distention. On further evaluation, the beta- hCG levels were persistently elevated and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the appropriate management in this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Methotrexate with folinic acid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Methotrexate with folinic acid: This is a clear case of post-molar choriocarcinoma with lung metastases. Treatment is based on prognostication and staging. According to the given scoring system, the parameters such as the time interval since the antecedent pregnancy, beta-hCG levels, and the presence of lung metastases suggest a low-risk choriocarcinoma. For low-risk choriocarcinoma, the recommended treatment is multi-dose single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate. Methotrexate is administered in a multi-dose regimen (Day 1, 3, 5, 7) alternating with folinic acid (Day 2, 4, 6, 8).
  • • Methotrexate with folinic acid:
  • • < 6: LOW RISK > 7 HIGH RISK
  • • < 6: LOW RISK
  • • > 7 HIGH RISK
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate alone might be considered for very low-risk cases. However, in this case, with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels and lung metastases, a multi-dose regimen along with folinic acid is preferred to enhance efficacy and reduce toxicity.
  • • Option B. Methotrexate:
  • • Option C. EMACO regimen: The EMACO regimen, which includes etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine, is used for high-risk choriocarcinoma. This patient's score indicates a low-risk profile, making EMACO unnecessary and more toxic than needed.
  • • Option C. EMACO regimen:
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for choriocarcinoma, especially in the context of low-risk metastatic disease. It may be considered in cases of heavy bleeding or when the disease is confined to the uterus and chemotherapy is not effective.
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low-risk choriocarcinoma post-molar pregnancy with lung metastases is treated with a multi-dose regimen of methotrexate alternating with folinic acid
  • ➤ Ref: Page 789, Williams Gynecology, 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 789, Williams Gynecology, 3 rd edition

questions.text: An adolescent male came with complaints of lesions all over the face and back, which were predominantly comedones. What is the most effective treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Systemic doxycycline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systemic doxycycline is the most effective treatment for moderate to severe acne that involves comedones and inflammatory lesions, particularly when the condition is extensive.

questions.text: Identify the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

questions.text: In iron deficiency anemia all of the following is increased except? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Transferrin saturation

questions.text: Sequence of Rigor Mortis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Head to foot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rigor mortis follows a sequence known as Nysten's Rule, developing and passing from head to foot, starting with the upper body and ending with the lower extremities.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following medications should be adjusted or stopped before the procedure? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stop Enalapril

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Before surgery, ACE inhibitors like Enalapril should be stopped due to the risk of refractory hypotension, while beta-blockers can be continued, and aspirin should be managed based on its dosage.
  • ➤ Hypertensive patients on Antihypertensives
  • ➤ Hypertensive patients on Antihypertensives
  • ➤ ACE Inhibitors - Omitted on day of surgery. Angiotensin receptor blockers - Omitted on day of surgery. Diuretics - Continued on the day of surgery. Beta Blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. Calcium channel blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. Centrally acting alpha-2 agonists - Continue on the day of surgery.
  • ➤ ACE Inhibitors - Omitted on day of surgery.
  • ➤ Angiotensin receptor blockers - Omitted on day of surgery.
  • ➤ Diuretics - Continued on the day of surgery.
  • ➤ Beta Blockers - Continue on the day of surgery.
  • ➤ Calcium channel blockers - Continue on the day of surgery.
  • ➤ Centrally acting alpha-2 agonists - Continue on the day of surgery.
  • ➤ ANTICOAGULANTS
  • ➤ ANTICOAGULANTS
  • ➤ Aspirin continued on day of surgery Clopidogrel - stopped 7 days prior to surgery Warfarin- stopped 5 days prior to surgery Heparin - stopped 4 hours prior to surgery LMWH-stopped 12 hours prior to surgery Ticlopidine - stopped 14 days prior to surgery BRIDGING DRUG - heparin.
  • ➤ Aspirin continued on day of surgery
  • ➤ Clopidogrel - stopped 7 days prior to surgery
  • ➤ Warfarin- stopped 5 days prior to surgery
  • ➤ Heparin - stopped 4 hours prior to surgery
  • ➤ LMWH-stopped 12 hours prior to surgery
  • ➤ Ticlopidine - stopped 14 days prior to surgery
  • ➤ BRIDGING DRUG - heparin.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the ER with a history of trauma two weeks back with confusion and ataxia. CT scan reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subdural haemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Subdural hematoma typically results from the rupture of bridging veins and presents without a lucid interval. CT scans of subdural hematoma show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.
  • ➤ Subdural hematoma typically results from the rupture of bridging veins and presents without a lucid interval.
  • ➤ CT scans of subdural hematoma show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.
